metadata.titleEn: The groundwater table data set in the lower of Heihe River (2011-2013)
metadata.description: Groundwater is the main water source of desert riparian plants, and also the most important environmental factor affecting the normal physiological status of plants. In this project, an observation field was set up in Populus euphratica forest near the Alxa Desert eco hydrological experimental research station from 2011 to 2013 By manually measuring the groundwater depth every month in the year, it can provide basic data support for the study on the transpiration water consumption mechanism of Populus euphratica, and also can be used for the estimation of ecological water demand in the study area.
metadata.instructions: Data file name: groundwater depth 2011-2013.xlsx; it can be viewed and edited by WPS, Excel and other software.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of groundwater depth data collected in desert riverbank ecosystems?
Feature Specification.Answer: monthly collection, 2011 to 2013, near Alxa Desert Eco-hydrology Experimental Research Station, poplar forest

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential impacts on the understanding of plant physiology and ecological water needs when using a dataset that measures groundwater depth in desert riparian areas from 2011-2013?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The dataset measuring groundwater depth in desert riparian areas provides crucial information about the primary water source for desert riparian plants, such as Populus euphratica. By collecting monthly data on groundwater depth from 2011 to 2013, researchers can gain insights into how fluctuations in groundwater levels affect the physiological status of these plants. This understanding can inform the development of strategies to estimate ecological water requirements and improve water resource management in desert ecosystems.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of collecting groundwater depth data in desert riparian forest ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective of collecting groundwater depth data in desert riparian forest ecosystems is to provide foundational data support for studying the transpiration water consumption mechanisms of Populus euphratica, as groundwater serves as the main water source for desert riparian plants and significantly influences their physiological status.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies can be employed to accurately measure and record groundwater depth in desert riparian ecosystems over an extended period?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Groundwater depth measurements can be conducted using manual methods on a monthly basis, as seen in the approach where an observation field is established near a desert riparian forest to support research on plant water use mechanisms and ecological water demand estimation.

Enablement.Question: What methods enable the accurate measurement of groundwater depth in desert ecosystems, specifically to support research on plant transpiration mechanisms?
Enablement.Answer: Groundwater depth in desert ecosystems is measured through monthly manual observations at designated monitoring sites, such as the observation field set up beside the Alxa Desert Ecohydrology Experimental Research Station, which provided foundational data for research on plant transpiration mechanisms from 2011 to 2013.
